author: Scott Forant

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

text: The president suffers from the Dunning‚ÄìKruger effect, it is a cognitive bias in which people of low ability have illusory superiority and mistakenly assess their cognitive ability as greater than it is. The cognitive bias of illusory superiority comes from the inability of low-ability people to recognize their lack of ability. Without the self-awareness of metacognition, low-ability people cannot objectively evaluate their actual competence or incompetence. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunning%E2%80%93Kruger_effect

text:
In Yuval Harari's book "Homo Deus", part 2, chapter 6, page 195 (I have a translated version, so exact page may differ) there is a graph of carbon dioxyde emmissions from 1970 to 2013. He shows that the growth (!) of emissions stops only in the period of economic recession. So, to combat global warming efficiently, economic growth should stop. Nobody wants to do that.
Say, you are rich. You want 3 % growth of your stocks ? Well, forget that.
Say you are poor. You want 15 $/hour minimum wage ? Well, with redistribution of wealth theoretically it would be possible, but as experience shows...
Say, you are a politician. Well, good luck in a debate against those who promise 3% and 15$/h...

Present day economy, especially finance, is basically founded on growth. To combat global warming, all people should unanimously make sacrifices. It's hard to do that individually, and incomparably harder to agree to do that in all parts of the world honestly.

This is the simple reason of all this stalling on this issue.

text:
The greenhouse effect is basic physics.
Climate change has of course happened since the "dawn of time", but always for specific reasons (milancovic cycles, sun activity, changes in greenhouse gases, etc.).
Right now, the main cause for the current change in climate is an increase in greenhouse gases that happen to originate from human activity.

Your claim that one volcanic eruption emits more CO2 than humans ever did is blatantly wrong, by the way.
Volcanoes actually emit around 1% of what humans emit.

text:
For the "This Is a Scam" morons - allow me to explain why we're having colder winters...

 First, let's start with a basic Principle of Science - It's impossible to generate energy from nothing. You just turn one type of energy into another type of energy (heat into motion, motion into electricity, electricity into motion, etc...). Energy transfer.

 You know those moments when you're having a glass of whisky and you put a cube of ice in it to cold the whisky?
 Well it happens because the cold temperature of the ice cube is transfered to your whisky, and vice-versa. And during that process you can observe the ice cube melting. Heat goes to the ice cube (energy that causes motion in ice water molecules, therefore melting) and the whisky looses heat.

 Now imagine you as living in the hot area (whisky), and the North Pole as being the Ice Cube...
 For some incredible reason, you are getting more cold coming from the poles (colder winters) each year, aren't you?
 That, my dumb friend, is BECAUSE THE FUCKIN' ICE CUBE IS MELTING!!!

 

 Now...
 Use Your brain, and try to guess why it melts. (faster each year, causing colder winters each year)

text:
I was going to say it's pretty awesome that a Republican administration acknowledges manmade climate change, but then I got to the bit where Rick Santorum says that scientists are just trying to cash in on the global warming hype, and by extension must be making up all of the data supporting it. Just... Honestly this makes me sad. Sometimes I get angry or incredulous, but this genuinely makes me sad. How cynical do you have to be to believe that people who dedicate their lives to furthering the knowledge of mankind and trying to understand the universe would be so petty, have such disregard the achievements of past scientific giants, and care so little for the well-being of their fellow human beings, that they would gather together to fabricate a worldwide catastrophe? 

I'm a physicist, and we certainly get Big Bang deniers, those who claim the Universe is not 13.8 B years old, but the idea that a former U.S. senator would make the baseless claim that an entire field of worldwide, peer reviewed science is perpetuated by frauds looking to make a quick buck is the most saddening example of disinformation I have heard in recent years. It is not misinformation; this is deliberately false => disinformation. Inflating your poll numbers or claiming to be more popular than you are is one thing, but claiming that the scientific community is a bunch of profit-driven charlatans is despicable.

text:
They changed the name from Global Warming to Climate Change in order to transform any observation into a proof:
- too much rain? Climate Change!!
- too little rain? Climate Change!!
- forest fires? Climate Change!!
- too cold for you? Climate Change!!
- no orgasm this month? Climate Change!!

This is how pseudoscience works. They decide a conclusion and then they look for evidence that supports their conclusions. 

Science works the other way around. It comes up with a theory and then experiments are made that try to contradict the theory. After a while, if all the experiments fail to contradict the theory, the theory is taught in schools. 

Climate Change is not a scientific theory. It makes no testable predictions.

text:
Why do people keep bringing both sides? Because there is NO consensus yet. The infamous John Cook study that pundits use to spout the "97% of scientists agree" does NOT say anything of the sort, and neither does any other similar study. For anyone who still believes the 97% BS, just look at what the actual study said, Cook et al:

1. It's NOT 97% of "all climate scientists", it's 97% ‚Äúamong climate authors taking a position‚Äù on man-made climate change, which is about a third. The other 2 thirds didn't think there was enough data to support a position at this moment (aka prudent scientists). 
So it's 97% of a third, which brings it down to 32%

2. The 97% figure is a sum of THREE numbers
Explicitly endorses and quantifies AGW as over 50% = 1.6%
Explicitly endorses but does NOT quantify or minimize = 23%
Implicitly endorses AGW = 72%

ONLY THE FIRST really holds a position that man-made climate change is a MAIN factor, the others acknowledge a human impact, but dont think there is enough information to QUANTIFY it, could be large, could be small.
So the number of alarmists is NOT 97%, is 1.6%.
It's 1.6% of a third, which comes down to a grand total of 0.5%

If you sell 0.5% as 97%, you are a complete hack.

My favorite author! well next to Victor Hugo of course. i always felt that Asimov was a great sociologist. 
as a Buddhist, i like to think that people think that very same thing and call it the 'middle path'. Nothing in Buddhism is about ignoring reality, or being dishonest about cause and effect. claiming otherwise is not the middle path. I've heard far too many American Buddhists claim that it is. compromise has nothing to do with the middle path in Buddhism. in modern society the middle path has a become a tool for the willfully ignorant and lazy who simply don't want to say the truth about anything and need a way to seem wise.

As a sociologist i see that our culture honors what Asimov described so much, that instead of smart people bringing other's up to their level, we actually punish intelligent people and bring them down to the levels of the worst of us. it's really quite an interesting phenomena that is all pervasive down to the very core of our cultural values.

text: ¬†@Franz Maier¬† how did cooling happen from an accelerated release of greenhouse gases? Isn't that antithetical to the gases being the major contributor of warming? Yes the sun has been relatively inactive as of recent. Hence the drop in global temperatures 1998-2007, even as CO2 increased 4%. To that note, global temperature has been relatively stagnant for two decades now, completely nullifying the 97% of paid government scientists and their modeling of a substantial increase during that time. author: Bagrilla Jenkins

text:
Cooling happened because the effects of the released aerosols outweighed the effects of the released greenhouse gases.
1998 was an exceptionally hot year. The warming trend has not actually stopped in the years after that.
Global temperatures have absolutely not been stagnant for two decades. They increased by almost half a degree.
author: Franz Maier

text: ¬†@Franz Maier¬† http://www.climatedepot.com/2017/05/25/analysis-of-latest-data-temperature-hasnt-risen-in-20-years/
author: Bagrilla Jenkins

text:
Like I said, 1998 was an exceptionally hot year.
You might be able to cherrypick one specific exceptionally cold month in more recent times and compare it to 1998 and come to the conclusion that "temperature hasn't risen in 20 years".
You have to be more skeptical when people pick numbers for no apparent reason.

Look at this: https://goo.gl/images/MZBwto

Is it useful to say that "there has been no warming since 1998"?
I really hope you see how it is not.
author: Franz Maier

text: ¬†@Franz Maier¬† this is why I prefer to look at the overall trends of cosmic radiation, ocean temperature change, global temperature change, co2 change. Looking at these in terms of global history as opposed to recent times gives a more accurate perspective. I would never argue against global warming, climate changes, CO2 change, etc. I believe, based on overall trends rather than recent, that anthropogenic activity is minimal conducive to global effect, given that we have been warmer, CO2 has been higher. To equate CO2 and temperature as the anomaly is to reject  solar activity, water vapor, cosmic radiation, ocean temperature, etc. The milankovitch cycle is a more accurate determining factor.
author: Bagrilla Jenkins

text:
As I described earlier, solar activity is not responsible for the vast majority of recent global warming. Neither are the milancovic cycles. Those are very predictable and operate on much larger timescales than hundreds of years.

Water vapor is actually quite important in explaining global warming, as it acts as a sort of leverage for an increase in CO2.
More CO2 causes slightly higher temperatures, which causes the atmosphere to be able to hold more water vapor, which in turn causes even higher temperatures (because water vapor is a very potent greenhouse gas) until a new equilibrium point is reached.

All those things are not ignored or rejected, they just happen to not be very significant.
author: Franz Maier

text: ¬†@Franz Maier¬† I agree that water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas as it makes up 95%. I just don't agree that the rise in CO2 is as critical as it's made out to be. It has risen what, 100 ppm in the last 50 years? The rise is approximately 1/100% or 0.01%? If I recall correctly, it has been at levels 10x current in history. I just don't see that sort of increase as dire as the IPCC would lead the public to believe. I think the global political environmental machine is bankrolling on hype. Its not unheard of for economic stability in the form of job security.
author: Bagrilla Jenkins

text:
¬†@Franz Maier¬† let me add another point to the CO2 issue that I forgot. If the ocean temperature lags behind global temperatures for 100-200 years, and it produces more CO2 by far, I would attribute much of temperature rise to such. Given numbers as follows in the way of CO2 contributions to the atmosphere:
Oceans-100's of gigatons/annually 
Bacteria-50 GT
Animals-150 GT
Humans-6.5 GT
Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, but  considering after the fall of communism and socialism, political activism needed a home and chose environmental issues. Thatcher didn't trust oil and coal industries and chose nuclear. Clean energy. Political climate funding went from 70M to 2B almost overnight to 1.5T today. Like I said, follow the money.
author: Bagrilla Jenkins

text:
CO2 concentrations have indeed been much higher than today, for example during the Cretaceous period. Consequently, the planet looked something like this: https://australianmuseum.net.au/image/map-of-world-late-cretaceous

I'm not that much into the politics around it all, but the IPCC is backed up and actively endorsed by almost every relevant institution in climate science and reflects the state of it accurately.

I think there is a misunderstanding of the carbon cycle. When oceans, bacteria or other animals emit CO2, they do no actually add new carbon to the system. Oceans emit large amounts of it, but they also take back in pretty much the same amount from the atmosphere. Animals got the carbon from their environment in food from plants, which took the carbon from the atmosphere.
The difference to human emissions is that we take carbon in the form of fossil fuels that has previously been trapped in the ground and newly introduce it to the system.
author: Franz Maier

text: ¬†@Franz Maier¬† as a wildlife biologist for 20 years and having worked for federal, state, and independent consulting agencies, I can assure you that I am intimately familiar with the carbon cycle. If you are not familiar with the politics of working for a federal government then you might not understand the bureaucracy of research funding. If I ask for $1M to study squirrels gathering nuts, I get nothing.  If I ask for $1M to study squirrels gathering nuts in relation to global warming I get a fat check. That's the way the system works. When the IPCC said the world was headed for a global ice age, then a few years later came back with just the opposite the governmental bodies went right along. They are a politically activist, megalomaniacal, fund sucking, global elitist, third world crushing machine that can't predict climate one decade out, much less one century. For every crack pot scientist they employ, I can find 10 reputable ones, many being Nobel prize recipients that disagree wholeheartedly. Yet the IPCC carries the narrative because they are a global entity with a platform, deep rooted agenda, and a microphone. I have seen their parametric manipulation of the mathematical modeling systems they employ to be easily biased and falsely manufactured with inconsistent sampling techniques i.e. using ships to take ocean temps from a harbor and at sea and then use the harbor temps in modeling as it fits their hyperbole at the time. By no means take my word for it Franz, all I ask is that people use critical thinking, research, and common sense to come to their own conclusions.

author: purple sundowns

text: ¬†@Cliffton Aspeling¬† #1) scientists in the 1900's called it 'global warming', but changed the term to 'climate change'  in the 1970s/1980s when they realized the majority of people don't understand the difference between weather and climate and were getting confused about this issue. #2) Areas, such as the Northeast, are experiencing arctic amplification. This happens when the ice that covers the arctic is reduced in size, creating more open water and more evapotranspiration (you see the same thing with the Great Lakes and the Lake Effect). The warmer the arctic becomes, the more sea ice decreases, reducing the reflective properties of the sea ice and replacing it with open water, which has a dark surface that in turn absorbs more heat from the atmosphere, making the water warmer (what we scientists call a negative feedback loop). The increased evapotranspiration alters jetstreams, which dip further south, bringing increased cold from the arctic to lower latitudes during the winter. There are two things that will alter with a changing climate: temperature and precipitation. Places like the Southwestern US will get hotter and drier (already see those trends in that region for the last 3 decades), whereas the Southern Appalachian Mountains will get hotter and wetter. Places in the Northeastern and the UK will be experiencing effects of arctic amplification and therefore will get colder winters.  Not all places will get hotter and drier. Some will get colder and wetter, some colder and drier, and some hotter and wetter. Climate is complex. Please look at the most recent IPCC report or our own government's Climate Assessment if you really want to understand the mechanisms and impacts of climate change . They summarize over 70 years of peer-reviewed research from thousands of scientists from hundreds of universities, institutions, and government agencies from all of the world.

text:
Look, I have lived with an astrophysicist whose focus is the sun. I knew about the solar minimum long before it was ever in the news, but the sun cooling the Earth only makes the situation more drastic. We have an Earth heating up and melting from rising temperatures caused here, while at the same time you have a sun decreasing that temperature. As you know, the cycles of the year change depending on how direct the sun's rays are on your area of the world. This is why when the sun hits the planet directly (aka summer) the rising temperatures take over, making hot humid conditions. When the sun is not directly striking an area (aka winter) it is severely cold.

Now take a look at spring and fall, the temperate seasons in temperate areas of the world. Since people seem unable to discern who to trust, then start using your ow eyes. In my own area of world, these seasons have gone from being temperate to hot and humid. There is no such thing as a cool moderate fall or spring anymore. So clearly, even with the minimum, it is not enough to overcome the heat we are causing, as the temperate seasons now favor heat, not cold.

Moreover, the crops that depend on these conditions are failing. I have watched with my own eyes the decline of the fields around me. The last 2 years have been the absolute worst, and if too many more continue like this then the grain and meat industry will be in serious trouble. Even the modified seed is struggling, but don't take my word for it, or anyone else's, go do your own research. Go ask a farmer how well his crops have been growing. Go ask them how well they grow in hot wet conditions that switch drastically to unseasonable colds. They don't. This is a real problem.
author: Megan

And that's not what I think but I'm sure many would put that argument to you. And obviously there are many other factors beyond GSM or global warming that go into climate change which I have had to express to multiple people it is very hard name a near impossible to express via YouTube comment section. I personally just do not believe that humans are causing all of these Super Storms or rapid weather fluctuations. I personally just think it's just a natural cycle of this planet and of our solar system.
author: DarkContrast

text:
¬†@DarkContrast¬† you should want to stop global warming, even if there is a cooling coming, for two reasons. 1) The sharp switch between hot humid weather to drastic cold is not good for crops, which we all depend on. They simply cannot grow. Like I said, go ask a farmer how well the crops have been. Crops don't grow well in swamp-like conditions. Think of how many farm industries you can name that are growing in swamps.  
2) Agriculturally speaking, cold is easier to combat than a swamp. So if you have to choose one, go with the lesser of the two evils.

I know that a lot of the people commenting on here have said that it isn't that they deny climate change is happening, but that they deny it is manmade. My response to that is, if we both think we are right, why not let science test both theories? Let's make the changes that we are told will make things better and see what happens. What negative consequences do you foresee that will outweigh giving the opposite side equal time to prove who is right? 

My guess is that you are thinking tax dollars, and you believe that these changes would be more expensive than the results they would show. However, in a country struggling to create jobs, isn't a new industry that would need more people to help implement this new idea a good thing? The technology needed to make changes is more likely to create rather than destroy incomes. Think of the American construction of highways and electric lines in the 30s and 40s. It created jobs with new technology. Why do you suppose this would be any different?

text:
¬†@randomperson8571¬†  Fiscally conservative, socially moderate Republican here.  Yes, I hate Trump with the passion of a thousand burning suns.  If you are a fiscal conservative, you hate him because he's doubled the deficit in less than two years, to over $1 trillion according to CBO projections.  Not to mention the wasteful corrupt spending by his cronies in the cabinet.  

If you are an advocate of capitalism, you hate him for artificially propping up the market with vast amounts of government spending, creating a market bubble that will pop sooner rather than later.  You also hate the blatant market interference created by him using twitter to punish companies that he doesn't like.  

If you support the Free Market, then you hate him for pushing job-killing tariffs that has cost our economy billions more than we got in tax cuts and has led to more government spending to prop up failing businesses (like $12 billion for farmers hit hard by tariffs), all for a trade war that will likely end like all trade wars in history have- with both sides stepping back and returning to the status quo, no winner, no victory, just economic devastation.  

If you are a conservative that supports the Rule of Law, you hate him for violating our  presidential norms by refusing to divest his businesses and using tax payer money to stuff his pockets every time he goes golfing; his protecting blatantly corrupt members of his cabinet; and for breaking Nepotism laws by hiring his daughter and son-in-law to work in the White House (and yes, I know the DOJ says it's not illegal now, but they said it was illegal in every other single administration after the laws were passed until DJT's personal minions took over the DOJ; so why the change now?)

If you support American leadership in the world, then you absolutely hate the mockery he's made of the US globally, by breaking treaties with our allies and supporting our enemies.  I understand real politic, but North Korea and Russia are not our friends, we can't trust them like Trump so blindly [and obviously] does.  

And yes, I'm socially moderate, so I could go on for several more hours on that front.  Unfortunately, moderate Republicans are a minority in the party.  I can't tell you how many times I've been called a Communist by Trumpists when I point out that Tariffs violate the very idea of a free market.

text: "We've just had two of the coldest years, biggest drop in global temperatures that we've had..." "Two of the coldest years" is a complete bald-face lie. Go to NASA GISS and look at the "Monthly Mean Global Surface Temperature" graph: no recent year is as cold as the average in the 1990s, let alone previous decades. "Biggest drop" is what you'd expect to happen each time we hit THE HOTTEST TEMPERATURE in hundreds of thousands of years. These denialist numbnuts are demanding global warming "prove itself" with a continually increasing mean temperature like an oven warming up, but people please please think about it! If we didn't get a big drop in temperature after each near-record hot year, then the Earth would hit 2¬∞C warming in a few decades, not by the end of the century. All these stupid lazy TV reporters have to do is put the graphs up while these denialist numbnuts twist the simple obvious truth that the average global temperature over time has gotten hotter and hotter.

text:
About the man made thing, I can accept there is debate. After all, climate has changed in the past. There were ice ages, and hot periods. So debate on that as much as you like.
What's not up for debate is that there IS climate change. Global Warming is perhaps the wrong name for it, because as soon as it snows people go 'where's the warming going?' while forgetting the 'Global' part. Also weather does not equal climate, but even there can you see changes.
When I was a kid (only 30 years ago) I played in the snow from november untill late januari. It came and went but you could be sure there was at least 2 inches of it for a week every month. Last year we got sleet three times, period. And this for the 5th year in a row. Flowers were blooming untill october, we had so little rain last summer farmers all around Europe started pumping rivers dry to water the crops.
These are only the things I see, as a citizen (to quote the lady). If I had acces to worldwide data (and knew how to interpret it), I think I would see al lot more change, and not for the better.
Instead of denying CC, we'd better start preparing for it. I don't think we can stop it, so we'll have to adapt or go extinct as a species.

text: I think it all too obvious that the news is trying to show a debate where there isn't really one. Sure there are those who want to deny climate change to various degrees and for various reasons, but few of them, if any, are credible scientists who are not in the pay of some corporate interest to do so. While we may not have all the facts yet, what facts we do have all support that climate change is happening and that what we humans are doing is having a negative impact. Whether or not it is the sole cause is a side issue. It doesn't change that under any circumstances we are impacting the environment in a negative manner, and should change that, and if we can stop our climate from going completely off the rails we should put in every effort we can.

text:
I am one assignment away from completing my four-year degree in environmental science! I'm graduating from university to go to work into this world. A government run by asshats who've forgotten everything they've learned in elementary school. Remember the water cycle? Where do you think snow comes from? Snow is just frozen water. Water is suspended in the atmosphere. When it gets too cold and too heavy, it precipitates as rain - or if it's below freezing, snow, ice, hail, etc. Ask yourselves this. Where does the water in the air come from?

It comes from the sun evaporating the oceans!!! More global warming, more evaporation, more snow. Why is this so difficult to understand? This is why climate scientists have switched from using "global warming" to "climate change," because people forget that weather has extremes on both ends of the thermometer! Climate change exacerbates those extremes, but the global temperature overall is what is increasing. Global warming (i.e. climate change) does not mean there won't be cold weather anymore.

text: I like how the conservative host complains that scientists can't make money from Exxon if they say global warming is real. What motivation do scientists have for lying about global warming being real? They lose out on that corporate money, and most climatologists aren't paid that well. Believe me, most of them wish global warming wasn't real, but they feel they have a duty to warn the public. Conservatives act is if global warming is all that justifies the existence of climatologists. Even if global warming wasn't real, we would still need people to monitor and study the climate. Climates change over time; wind patterns change, the amount of precipitation in different areas change, the Earth is even getting closer to the Sun. The climate has a huge economic impact, it can cause natural disasters (hurricanes, floods, wild fires), lead to fires breaking out at oil refineries or other chemical plants, to health impacts (heat stroke, spread of tropical diseases), to making people late for work because they are driving through a storm, to name a few things. Really, global warming isn't some grand conspiracy to keep climatologists in a job.

text:
Don't get me wrong, climate change IS real - and excess greenhouse gases ARE the culprit, BUT NOTHING can be done. It's never been in the hands of mankind unless of course, it is possible for mankind to control the magnetosphere (which helps block dangerous solar radiation) allowing the sun to heat up the oceans faster than ever in recorded history. The oceans aren't heating up faster as a result of global warming, rather; the heating up of the oceans IS WHAT'S CAUSING IT. 

Large bodies of water heat up very slowly, moving large bodies of water even slower still, even if the average air temperature was 10-15 degrees (F) higher than it is - this wouldn't be enough to cause the kind of spikes in ocean temperature that is happening all around. The reason why the temperature of the ocean is so critical has to do with cloud cover which is a major factor in how much heat gets trapped close to the surface of the earth. 

It seems to me that the main take away from forwarding an agenda that says humanity can do something to save the day is to 
1] First and foremost to give people hope that something can be done - right up until the last moment  - this will hopefully prevent mass hysteria and pandemonium...I understand that messages like mine are a bit alarmist and counterproductive when considered in this light, but it's far better that people consider this and get ahead of it rather than find out at the last minute when shit WILL REALLY be bad because of the perceived betrayal whilst civilization as we know it is about to die with those few million remaining pointing fingers at each other saying you didn't do enough...

2] The second is the more nefarious idea that profit and power can be made off of manipulating the political/economic machinations of a society all too reliant on dino power in hopes that people will just make the planet a nicer place to live in before we all die...

Either way, we're fucked. My two cents for what they're worth in this shitty economy. Peace.

text:
The same is happening in Ohio.  We don't get spring or fall weather anymore, just extreme heat, extreme cold, and a whole lot of soggy soggy weather.  So many plants, native and cultivated, are struggling.  Even the gmo crops are struggling, and they were designed to withstand extreme conditions.  

When I was a kid we had 3 hard winter months with lots of snow and ice (December, January, February), then March was soggy and cold, then April was cool (in the 50+ degree range but beautiful sunny spring weather. May continued much the same way, gradually warming to the 60s, until around the 25th of the month, it seemed to heat up to the 70s.  June was beautiful and green, staying in the 70s, until around the 27th of the month, then the July heat kicked in.  July and August were miserable months, especially August, which could get to the 100s, and July was full of terrible thunderstorms.  Then September started to cool to the 70s, with a potential frost by the end of the month.  October was cold, sunny, and full of fall color, maybe a rainy day here or there.  November was gray, no leaves, and cold.  All this led us back to the last week of November, when the snow would start to fall, and there was always snow for Christmas.  If you look at some anecdotes from history, this was normal Ohio weather.  There was even an expression, "Don't like Ohio weather? Just wait, it'll change."  We had every kind of weather for every kind of person.  Now all we get is muggy, wet, heat, and occasional bouts of bitter, biter cold.

The first time I saw this crap was in 1998.  We got a reprieve for a few years, from about 2006-2012, but now it's been getting even worse than before.  Sadly, some kids today, who have grown up in Ohio, think this is the normal weather and don't have a clue!

text:
¬†@Jeff Novack¬† The point Im trying to make is that while humans are capable of impacting the climate, the universe is far more capable.  Is that a good reason not to try to prevent climate change and namely sea level rise, probably not.   

But that being said, maybe some greater good can be ultimately achieved as a result of climate change and the possible humanitarian crises that follow.  Only time will tell...   Humans will live on.  Maybe not with society as we know it, but honestly, climate change wont likely cause the collapse of society, something else might but not climate change.  Hell, we'll probably have way more potential to wipe out our current civilization long before climate change can do that much damage to the species as a whole.

Our society post-industrial revolution and even more so in the information age seems to think society as we know it is invincible, but its not, no matter how hard we may try to preserve it.

text:
The Mayans knew about climate change back in 700BC and prob earlier as well. That's what the long count calendar is for. It's "long term" climate changes. Just like everything is cycles on earth, there are long term "seasons" that last for 10 000 to 25 000 years or so. Ice age was "Winter" season , We just finished "Spring" season in 2012 and now is the slow warming up to "Summer" for the next 10 000 to 25 000 years. 

What people don't get is that ignorance is DEFINITELY not going to be bliss my friend. Whether we contribute to climate change is short term in the greater scale of time on Earth. 

The earth is a recycling machine, just another cycle like the climate. There is NOTHING that we can do that the earth cannot reverse.  Try 5 extinction level events and yet life still clings to this planet. 
PUNY HUMANS. lol 

It's what it does, it cycles and recycles. Give the earth 50 million years after us to recover and it will be like we were never here to begin with. :-)  

The only questions is.............will we adapt and move out into space or die fighting among ourselves for the little resources,food and water that we have. Cause all this time and effort in advancing the human race is going to mean sh*t if we can't survive on the planet due to climate changes or even self destruction. So far self destruction looks like the front runner at the moment.

text:
WHY are "deniers" willing to risk all of humanity (including themselves), their offspring, future descendants, on the slim chance that it wouldn't really matter?

Consider these scenarios:
A) Climate change ISN'T real
B) Climate change IS real 

and the two courses of action,
1) DO SOMETHING about it (lower greenhouse gases, minimize emissions, switch to green energy,  etc.)
2) DO NOTHING about it

result:
IF A & 1 = Nothing happens, world becomes a better place
IF A & 2 = Nothing happens, world remains as is
BUT
IF B & 1 = Maybe a catastrophe can be averted
If B & 2 = Potentially end of humanity as we know it.

So DOING SOMETHING will result in either averting a catastrophe OR a better world
while
DOING NOTHING will result in either no change , OR potential apocalyptic results
EVEN if you were a skeptic, would you be willing to bet on those odds and those consequences?

WHO pushes for the belief that climate change IS real = almost ALL scientific societies?
WHO pushes for the belief that climate change ISN't real = some geniuses on Youtube?

WHY would anyone push for NOT DOING ANYTHING?

text:
I hate that CNN, in its pained attempts to be ‚Äúbalanced,‚Äù feels compelled to bring people like Rick Santorum on their shows.

No, Rick Santorum‚Äôs opinion on climate change is not of equal weight or value to those of the people actually studying it. He‚Äôs entitled to his opinion, yes, but his opinion should not be considered equal to the data being studied and reported on by actual scientists.

I don‚Äôt adhere to the ‚Äústay in your lane‚Äù ideology. People should feel free to talk about things they don‚Äôt understand; that‚Äôs one of the ways we learn, after all. But if you are uninformed about something, as in you HAVE NOT STUDIED IT, your opinion is outranked by the opinions of people who are informed. You don‚Äôt have to stay in your lane, but know when to yield the goddam mic.

I love too how the conspiracy theories like ‚Äúscientists would be out of work without climate change‚Äù imply that scientists are only interested in climate change for the money and therefore we can‚Äôt trust what they say, when the opposition is coming from oil and fossil fuel companies, aka businesses that literally are ONLY IN IT FOR THE MONEY.

So, to recap, scientists allegedly are just in it for the money, so we can‚Äôt trust them, but the fossil fuel industry flat out is only in it for the money, but we can totally trust them. That‚Äôs Santorum‚Äôs argument in a nutshell.

Plus, Rick... scientists would be looking for work if not for climate change? Are you fracking kidding me?! Do you have any idea how many things scientists could be studying INSTEAD OF climate change?! Space travel, the depths of the oceans, mapping the human genome, cures for disease, there are literally hundreds of things the money going into climate change research could be funding, but nope, people like Rick and Trump and that idiot who brought the snowball into Congress to ‚Äúprove‚Äù climate change isn‚Äôt real just don‚Äôt get it, so we have to keep studying it and reporting on it, and having our studies thrown back in our faces as not good enough, not meeting impossible standards of proof, or in the case of Trump, just a flat out stubborn ‚Äúno, I don‚Äôt believe it.‚Äù

Ugh... fine. I‚Äôm gay; I‚Äôm not having kids. Your offspring‚Äôll be dealing with the fallout of your staggering ineptitude, not mine.

author: DarkContrast

text:
¬†@Operative 6-12¬† While I agree completely with just about everything you've written, there is one aspect of American driving that could make car ownership a little more justifiable. The fact that the states...many of which are larger than some countries...are spread out over thousands of miles.....and our light rail/train systems are SO inferior, compared to some other countries, that this mode is not really an option for many of us. Add to that having an occupation that requires you to haul equipment or instruments...which makes having a personal vehicle pretty essential.

That said......I find it appalling that American auto makers, in particular, have been in bed with the oil industry for decades...to ensure that "consumers" have virtually no options when it comes to owning a truly fuel-efficient and non-polluting automobile. I recently bought a 2007 Honda CR-V...a decent car, but with a totally unacceptable 24 MPG average....4 MPG LESS than the falling-apart 2001 Nissan Frontier I traded in. Had price not been the primary deciding factor, you can be sure I would have opted for a much more fuel-efficient vehicle. Unfortunately, finding that in my price range is a near impossibility.....and probably quite intentional manipulation by auto makers and their co-conspirators, Big Oil.

I carpool and find alternatives, when possible...but as long as the two industries are allowed to control the narrative and control the product (and the pricing), those of us who cannot afford the hybrids and electric cars currently on the market will have little choice but to continue adding to the problem. I apologize for my part in it all, but until there are affordable alternatives available to me, I and millions just like me will have little choice but to continue depending on our gas-guzzling polluters to get us to where we have to be.

text: It should be pointed out that scientists don't receive any money, not even a few grand, from putting out a paper or book.  What do scientists receive from their big grants? $0. text:
You could blame the media for part of this. They like to take published science papers and over simplify the subject matter. If someone knows absolutely nothing about science, it's understandable that they'd be skeptical about "global warming" if they see it getting cold. They don't understand what it means and they're just following the title. Bad title given to an unknowledgable public is always going to end badly.  It's the same argument as "if monkeys evolved into people, why are there still monkeys?". Because monkeys didn't turn into people, it's a shared ancestry. But once again, media headlines overly dumbed it down so people who don't know the science are making the only logical conclusion they can with what information they were given. And they really do this with everything, not just big topic issues.

Of course, even if I do sit here grumbling at the media for over simplifying it, the blame is not entirely theirs. There is something very wrong in a country where something as concrete as tested and retested scientific evidence is seen as a damned political stance. How does that make any sense? Climate change is not an opinion, it's not a left vs right or liberal vs conservative issue. So why are we pretending it is? The arguments basically come down to scientific results versus people who are scared of change and are hoping it'll go away on its own. That's not a real debate.

text:
¬†@DarkContrast¬† 
Indeed, studies show that solar variability has played a role in past climate changes. For example, a decrease in solar activity is thought to have triggered the Little Ice Age between approximately 1650 and 1850, when Greenland was largely cut off by ice from 1410 to the 1720s and glaciers advanced in the Alps.

But several lines of evidence show that current global warming cannot be explained by changes in energy from the sun:

Since 1750, the average amount of energy coming from the sun either remained constant or increased slightly.

If the warming were caused by a more active sun, then scientists would expect to see warmer temperatures in all layers of the atmosphere. Instead, they have observed a cooling in the upper atmosphere, and a warming at the surface and in the lower parts of the atmosphere. That's because greenhouse gases are trapping heat in the lower atmosphere.

Climate models that include solar irradiance changes can‚Äôt reproduce the observed temperature trend over the past century or more without including a rise in greenhouse gases.

https://climate.nasa.gov/causes/

They disagree with you.

text:
quantumperception
My cousin got his degree in marine biology from UCT (University of Cape Town - South Africa) just shy of 25 years ago, has travelled all over the planet and been witness to the havoc global warming is wreaking on our oceans. Initially, upon hearing from the misinformed/disinformed, willfully ignorant and quite often entirely deluded "deniers" claims that scientists are conspiring to perpetrate a hoax for the money he was amused. That soon gave way to anger and now, unfortunately, he seems to have adopted something of a fatalistic attitude. The last time we spoke he said to me, (I'm paraphrasing), Vic, I've been trying for nearly half my life to get through to people and I've encountered everything from outright hostility to deliberate ignorance to apathy. Nothing I say or do seems to make any difference. I'm almost at the point where I don't care any more.
I'm not sure I blame him.

text: ¬†@Andr√°s B√≠r√≥¬† There is also part of me that hopes about technology solving the problem as well, though we shouldn't become complacent. People a long time ago worried that humanity was facing a similar problem, in that population was growing so fast that we could not grow enough food to feed every one, and that would bring about starvation, war, economic collapse, etc. However, shortly thereafter, the agricultural revolution happened. I remember watching this video about previous examples of when scientists and intellectuals thought "the world would end", and how all of those cases were averted by technology solving the problem. Even now, people are coming up with solutions to solve the floating trash island, for instance.  I think it is a total possibility that some genius will come up with a technological solution to the problem, but I also don't want to let that make us become complacent, because then it won't happen. It is a serious problem that demands our attention, but I also don't rule out the idea that some tech genius can come up with a solution to solve the problem either. In other words, we should do what we can to combat the problem now, but we also shouldn't commit suicide because we are all doomed.

text:
@Emma With The Gs
"I guess for CNN it's damned if you do, damned if you don't. CNN gets flack all the time they're too liberal. They have no choice but to present both sides."

1) Not, only does CNN have the ability & capability to choose who is & isn't allowed on-air. Journalists love to claim that real journalism is about being "objective" but "presenting both sides" isn't "objectivity" it is "neutrality". Now, it is great if on any given topic all sides stick to facts, base their claims & views on reality, etc... because this allows both objectivity & neutrality. However, if it is raining outside & 2 people step outside then come back in to give their views on what the weather outside is & 1 of them says it is raining while the other one says it is sunny allowing them both to present their side/view of the question is neutral, it is in fact the opposite of objective. People can have all sorts of views, opinions, etc... on the same topic while they all also deal in facts. But, any organization supposedly engaged in real journalism not only has the choice, but they have the obligation to not allow any side on any topic the opportunity to present "their side" when they reject facts & lie.

2) CNN is not "damned if you do, damned if you don't." Republicans/Conservatives have constantly complained about the "liberal media" [non-existant in major, mainstream journalism organizations unless by 'liberal' people mean someone who isn't a complete bigoted as-hole & believes everyone has a right to some very limited, minimal amount decency in how they are treated... then yeah these organizations are 'liberal' but so is the vast majority of the planet.] They continue to complain about it, & guess what they will continue complaining about not matter how f-cking far backwards organizations go to allow Republican/Conservative propagandists the ability to present "their side" of things. However, Democrats [or even for that matter people actually on the left side of the political spectrum,] will not be constantly complaining about stuff these organizations do if they stop allowing blatant & obvious liars to spread lies, especially not the Democrats. The people on the left would still have some complaints about the way a small number of topics are covered, but trust me we don't expect any of them to cover those specific topics any differently & will not be making any public fuss about it just grumbles amongst ourselves.

The way they operate now they catch flak from all sides, participate in spreading lies, & completely violate the 1 supposed aspiration of their profession. They have the ability to actually try to live up to their self-professed ideals & stop the legitimate flak being hurled their direction. The idea that views, beliefs, etc... which are blatant & obvious lies/falsehoods is somehow legitimate simply because 1 of the 2 major political parties in our country & roughly a little less than 50% of the population choose to believe it [for the voters at least... I'm absolutely positive that the officials, donors, party elite propagating them don't believe those things they are merely saying them,] is an absolutely absurd notion.

text: ¬†@James V¬† On your proposal that climate change has been happening for billions of years, I agree with you. The point at which I disagree with you is the time period over which they have taken place. Show to me at any point in history where the ppm of CO2 has risen at the rate that it has over the period since the industrial age. I think you will find that you won't find much at all data because the increase of CO2 particles in the atmosphere has changed over hundreds of thousands of years, not a few decades. Over the past 400 thousand years, approximately the amount of time that the genus Homo Sapiens has existed on this planet, the highest CO2 concentration was approximately 280 ppm but in the time since the 1800s the carbon dioxide concentration in our atmosphere has increased from 250ppm to well past over 400ppm. YES, the CO2 concentration was higher during the existence of the dinosaurs but we never evolved to survive those levels of CO2 in our atmosphere because we have never been exposed to them before. It can't just be a simple coincidence that our use, as a species, of petroleum-based energy since the beginning of the 1800s has coincided with the fastest growth of CO2 in our atmosphere, in not just recorded history but the past 60 million years. It simply can't be blamed on the atmospheric carbon cycle.

Joe van holbeck¬†So I looked through the comment thread and I have a few things I thought I'd say first thing it's not about trusting an authority it's about trusting the scientific consensus right now the vast majority of climate scientist think that global warming is real and we are the primary contributor to it so it's reasonable to assume that this is the case. 
Second think for a few minutes, who benefits from your conspiracy theory. not the politicians it's not like the taxes are going towards their salary. Not the MSM, because how would they profit from increased taxes? No one involved in pushing the agenda would benefit from the increased taxes because you know they would go towards building shit.
 Thirdly again back to the scientist, are they being payed off to push this agenda? If so by whom?
 Fourthly what parts of man made climate change are you sceptical of? The enormous amount of CO2 we've introduced? You seem to recognize CO2 increases cause global warming since you brought up that point about how CO2 levels in Ice cores so it's probably not that part and I just can't think of another reason other than those two to doubt it so I feel like to convince you I need to know what parts of man made global warming you aren't buying.
 Sixthly you are right that currently measures taken to decrease our impact on global warming, ie. Building Wind/solar farms,  contribute to the amount of CO2 in the air which is why it's so important we get it over with now while we still have some room in the carbon budget to spare because once the means of manufacturing, and the means of extracting and transporting resources as well as power production don't produce CO2 you can produce things without adding CO2 and every step along the way to that end produces less carbon than the former.
Fiinally global warming happened in the past is not a counter to we are causing global warming because of the fact that we can have an impact on the same factors that caused global warming in the past.

text:
Climate change: this is the worst scientific scandal of our generation
Our hopelessly compromised scientific establishment cannot be allowed to get away with the Climategate whitewash, says Christopher Booker.
What is tragically evident from the Harry Read Me file is the picture it gives of the CRU scientists hopelessly at sea with the complex computer programmes they had devised to contort their data in the approved direction, more than once expressing their own desperation at how difficult it was to get the desired results.

The third shocking revelation of these documents is the ruthless way in which these academics have been determined to silence any expert questioning of the findings they have arrived at by such dubious methods ‚Äì not just by refusing to disclose their basic data but by discrediting and freezing out any scientific journal which dares to publish their critics' work. It seems they are prepared to stop at nothing to stifle scientific debate in this way, not least by ensuring that no dissenting research should find its way into the pages of IPCC reports.

text: Trump doesn't believe in climate change - or at the very least doesn't like the concept of "climate change" - because a) he's a moron who hasn't been in school in 50 or so years and therefore just doesn't believe modern science and b) government regulations put in place to curb climate change can cost wealthy corporations lots of money. He put stooges like former EPA chief Scott Pruitt into prominent positions within his administration to ease or completely remove regulations so corporations can spend less money (and therefore pocket that money) on things like environmentally safe disposal of waste and the limiting of emissions. So when Trump proudly spouts on about how he's rolling back government regulations, that's what he s talking about. But people just cheer and clap along because it sounds great to have less government meddling in our lives, not realizing that the regulations he's rolling back are letting more and more companies pour more poison into our land, seas, and air. Trump sees environmental regulations as roadblocks preventing profits, and he emphasizes the economy above all of his other "achievements". He brags about how well the economy is doing under his administration, because that's a major selling point to get re-elected, the environment be damned. But when the climate becomes too harsh for most people - i.e. poor people - to live comfortably, he and his brood, along with all the wealthy people who have profitted the most from the way things have been, just won't care at all. They'll just use their wealth to buy boats they can live on while everyone else drowns, or build a space station in orbit like the movie Elysium while we all suffocate. Survival of the richest.

text:
When I see something like this, not just about America, but any country, I always wonder: why are these people, the leaders of the world, allowing the world die? 
Not just Trump, but any world leader, the ones that make false promises about going to make changes to stop climate change, the ones that don't believe it, or try to make it happen faster by cutting more rain forests down, or make more pollution by building bigger industries.

These leaders should make rules about this, stricter rules, but also more rewarding rules, simple things like rewards in money for those who switch over to becoming none-polluters, give a reward for those who switch to solar panels to power their daily lives, help the people that want to do so, making solar panels the normality on houses, build them with solar panels as roof.
Or make electric cars more wide-spread, and more price efficient than those who guzzle gas.

But even if the world leaders don't change, You, the person reading this, still can. 
Too many people just accept it, letting it happen, just waiting for all the things you love to become destroyed, coffee for example, chocolate, beer, drinkable water and soon many more things most people enjoy day to day are in more trouble every month that we let it continue.

Then people blame money, the greed of corporations, the rich getting richer, etc.
Without any changes in how we use fossil fuel for everything from electricity to driving, all the money in the world isn't going to save you, when the world itself stops functioning.

Please help by doing your part, every day you decide to ride a bike, walk, take the train, is a day of your vehicle not polluting, every day you decide to eat vegan, is a day of not needing more methane producing livestock for you and whoever you convince to join you, and every solar panel you have, is another large chunk of coal not going into the power plant.

Every day of people doing their part, might give the planet another day that doesn't involve its self destruction. 

Do it for people you love, for all humans, for any animals you love, and as a thanks for Earth, and everything Earth did for you, show Earth some love back for all the hard work it does for you, it deserves it. ‚ù§

text:
Uhmmm. I'm as infuriated as Trevor is. The predictive science, not only a compilation of the 4 years in the report... But of already decades and even thousands of years of data taken from studying the past (studying the ice samples from Antarctica) says that the temperature of the planet is warming up (to clarify, that is the average temperature of all the data compiled in the planet per year). This means, some places are getting colder (not the poles since they are melting so fast that if it was a race, every year a speed record would be broken), and some places are getting hotter, Thus the definition of climate change, but the average of these temperatures all together for the year is warmer (because people couldn't understand global warming we now use climate change).

Now since the average person understands this and there are still those that refuses the data, the facts, the evidence... What does that mean? What does it mean if your fuel tank indicator says your car is going empty and you refuse to acknowledge the reading? Do you keep driving until it is too late to fill it at a gas station or do you fill it? You get a fever and the doctor tells you that you are sick, you need rest, medication, and proper food... Will you just refuse the diagnosis and do whatever you want and die, or do you take the ttreatmen? The planet is telling you that it can't take the crap any more. Earth will still be there but we might find it difficult to cope with the changes once the lakes go dry, once the lands get flooded, once the weather hazards get stronger, etc. Not only will our own homes be affected but our source of food will disappear. Farms, fish, conditions for growing plants and for animals to survive (our food) will be affected. And yet, the diagnosis, the meter indication, the data, the facts, the evidence... Is being ignored, but by who? Who is ignoring or wishes to ignore it? Why are they ignoring it? If you ask me... Fossil fuel, the companies that use it, the companies that extract it from the planet, not people that drive cars, no. We, all together driving cars, do not even come close to the companies that use it and extract it. So who is going out of their way to say that the data is of no importance? I wonder.

text: ¬†@Swissboy362 Gaming Channel¬† well it just so happens that I am a scientist who has done research since 1997, and with that caveat of yours you shall like me but you won't like what I have to say. The reason behind your beliefs is evident by your statements, references,  and blind allegiances. You may not be aware of the composition of the IPCC in terms of it's allegiances. Let me assure you there is no nobility in deriding dissenting evidence as heresy.   The budget for climate study has grown from 70 million to 1.5 trillion in two decades. Why? The global temperature went up about 1 degree in 150 years and according to IPCC modeling 30 years ago it should have increased 3-5 degrees. Why hasn't it? They said that by now snow would be a thing of the past. Is it? Are you aware that while your country is warming, the southern hemisphere is cooling? Do you know the composition of greenhouse gases? 95% of the gases are water vapor. In the atmosphere CO2 makes up 0.04%. Anthropogenic activity accounts for one third of the CO2. That's 0.013%. Rather minuscule in comparison to nitrogen, oxygen, argon wouldn't you say? Why is the troposphere not warming if that's where the greenhouse gases collect? Why did global temperature decrease during the industrial age(1940-1975)? Why did the IPCC change/omit scientific contributions in response to comments by individual governments and NGO's? I am aware the globe is warming. I am aware climate changes. I refute the level of human involvement claims to be crisis level. It is moderate at best, more so rather insignificant. An organization vying for federal funding for survival will inextricably be biased. If you choose to be a sheep, you will be welcome at the slaughter.

text:
¬†@Perry B.¬† Research doesn't cure stupidity. I'm a plant molecular biologist, and there are tons of things we could do right now to help lots of people and the environment, but we're 'not allowed to', because 'people' don't want us to.
There are 2 kinds of stupidity, 'Physiological', where somebody literally can't understand things, and 'Optional', where somebody chooses to embrace ignorance and irresponsible decisions even though they're perfectly capable of understanding the issues.
For physiological stupidity, we should try to find better ways to teach and explain things, and put some (though not limitless) effort into helping those who are struggling.
For optional stupidity, somebody has to choose to 'cure' themself, nobody else can 'cure' them while they remain alive.
Under certain conditions, optional stupidity ceases to be merely annoying, and poses a threat to many other people besides the person who is choosing to be ignorant, dishonest, and irresponsible. Under those conditions, clearly intervention is necessary, and ideally, you can just pass laws that forbid willfully destructive behavior, and destructive actions can be treated just like any other crime. Unfortunately, in our system, for this issue, the people who are choosing to be stupid are often in charge, and even when people who aren't stupid get in power, they act like cowards, refusing to stand up for what is right, or exercise their power responsibly.

My hands are not completely clean. I have burned fossil fuel in my life, and while I actively try to avoid doing so, I have in some ways contributed to this problem. However, when given feasible choices, I will go out of my way to mitigate the impacts I have on the environment, and so should everyone else. We all bare responsibility in this, but we've made enough excuses, we've wasted enough time, and we've let liars and thieves steer us in a terrible direction for long enough. There are things we can do to at least slow this disaster down, and surrendering to those acting in bad faith is not only cowardice, but a betrayal of our responsibilities.

"Your graphs and reality haven‚Äôt been the same for 50 years."
I have a question. Could you be so helpful as to name the cognitive defect that has lead you to conclude that 50 year old data somehow outdoes the latest developments? It's like using Windows 95 to criticize Windows 10.

author: The White Guardian

text:
¬†@James V¬† 
I just love it when people provide their age, cognitive dexterity, and IQ all in a single post. Just a nice "hello, I'm an infantile Dunning-Kruger sufferer" and no beating around the bush.

If anyone wants proof that you have no idea what you're talking about, allow me to dissect this offering of mental manure.

"You sheeple are the same who backed Al Gore when he said our eastern seaboard would be gone by 2017."
Resorting to calling your opponents the sheeple already? Save your arrogance until after you've made a point, kiddo.

"Washington DC should be underwater if you virtue signaling shitbrains were right 20 years ago."
Non sequitur. Are you really so stupid or dishonest that you see no other excuse but to refer to an outdated quote (YOU said that it was twenty years ago)? Scientific understanding is refined over time by definition - otherwise it wouldn't be science.

So once again, are you stupid, dishonest, or smoking tide pods? What excuse do you have for pretending that something a non-scientist said 20 years ago outdoes the current scientific understanding?

"There is a NATURAL cycle to global climate."
That is not the argument, skid mark. To use a metaphor: you've missed the goal, hit the tree beside it, and are now running around the soccer field shirtless screaming bloody murder in excitement.

If you can't even recognize what the argument is about, why should anyone give a rat's arse about your pitiful conniption fit?

"Volcanos emit more carbon and sulfur emission into the atmosphere in one explosion than the entirety of human history."
Wrong.
Humans emit around 29 billion tons of CO2 each year.
Adding up all estimates of volcanoes (degassing, historically active, volcanic lakes, emissions from tectonic, hydrothermal and inactive volcanic areas, and emissions from mid-ocean ridges) leads to an estimate of 645 million tons of CO2 annually.

To compare:
Humanity: 29 000 000 000 tons
Volcanoes: 640 000 000 tons
What's your excuse for this blatant lie of yours?

Maybe pay attention in science class before you try to play teacher.

"It is well documented in the ice cores pulled from Antarctica."
Yet you couldn't be bothered to provide an example.

"And more recent studies show that our warming and cooling cycles are HIGHLY affected by the SUN."
Again, CITATION NEEDED!

"Ya know that giant ball of FIRE"
No, skid mark. The sun isn't fire. Fire is a chemical reaction between a combustible substance and oxygen in the atmosphere. The flames are simply light emitted by the sheer temperature as described by Wien's law.

Our sun also emits light as per Wien's law, but it's not heated through a chemical reaction with oxygen. The sun's heat is a product of the nuclear fusion happening inside the sun's core, NOT a reaction with oxygen.

The sun is PLASMA, not FIRE. Again, listen to what is said in science class before you attempt to delude yourself into believing you're some kind of expert on the subject.

"emmiting large doses of heat and radiation"
You appear to be too incompetent to realize that those are the same thing. The heat of the sun that we feel is brought here by radiation: infrared for example.

'heat emission' is LITERALLY emitting electromagnetic radiation. This is high school level physics, and you've just shown that you don't understand it.

"in the form of flares."
Partially correct. Emission of electromagnetic radiation is not limited to just solar flares. I really don't know why you felt the need to bring them up as they serve no purpose in your "point".

"Oh btw if you virtue signal tards are that scared about it you better stop breathing now because you exhale carbon."
Except they actually produce something of merit while doing so, whereas you are wasting oxygen proudly presenting your own ignorance online.

You're like a child presenting their crappy crayon drawings as if we ought to consider them comparable to a Picasso.

"I mean if you care about the children/world."
If we're going to be discussing intention: what were you trying to achieve by proudly presenting to the rest of the world that you failed high school physics?

Try to edit your responses of unnecessary material before attempting to impress us with your insight, you pretentious native of the silver throne.

text:
¬†@William Inbody¬† 
Amazing. So your excuse for over three million scientific reports disagreeing with you is just whining about conspiracies and poisoning-the-well allegations?

Pardon me, but are you stupid enough to believe that anyone is going to accept that for an answer? Your desperate attempt to gain some ground through tactics that even a seven year old would cringe at is so incredibly opaque that it's nothing short of insulting to the intelligence of anyone reading what you wrote there.

Now then; wipe that drool of your chin and wash those brown stains out of your clothing, then come back here and at least attempt to provide a meaningful answer rather than desperately whining about conspiracies.

Since you're most definitely not clever enough to notice this unaided, allow me to elaborate: your allegations require substantiation, and until you provide some, your meaningless objections are void and your intellectual integrity is as non-existent as your scientific literacy. Prove that Google "controls what I see", prove that Google has an "agenda to destroy gas and oil industries in USA[sic]". Otherwise, by your own standards, AS I'VE SAID BEFORE:

Dragons are real, unicorns live behind a magic door in my basement, cheese = illuminati spies, and I'm secretly a wizard. Before you open your mouth to mock that response - it's as devoid of substantiation as yours is. Either accept that I'm a wizard, or accept that you're a hypocrite in public.

At least attempt to behave like a grown up when you pretend to know better than people who actually bothered to educate themselves on the subject, lest you'll turn yourself into a complete laughing stock.

TL;DR: act your age, not your d*ck size, then try to impress others with your "insight."
author: The White Guardian

text:
¬†@John Hall¬† Amazing. So the best you could come up with is poisoning-the-well allegations. How intellectually honest of you. Do you actually expect what you wrote there to be taken seriously? Because in that case you might have greater problems to deal with.

"These high priests of the global warming religion duped millions into believing that electricity to charge batteries and back up billion dollar bird-killing and landscape-blighting solar and wind machines comes from the tooth fairy and not 24/7 reliable nuclear or fossil fuels."
The tooth fairy? THIS is what I'm talking about. John, you simply suck at lying. Normally I'd tell people as obsessed with exploring their own digestive system as you are to grow a pair because lying is bad, but in your case, your attempts at misleading are so indescribably opaque that the fact that you actually expect others to believe you is nothing short of insulting.

And THAT is the most obscene part: it's not just that you insist on dishonesty, it's also that you insult the intelligence of our species while doing so.

"For a five minute primer on climate from an MIT physicist, not goofy nonsense from ignorant and/or corrupt bureaucrats, celebrities, journalists, greenie weenies, and politicians, see: Climate Change: A Short Summary"
After what you wrote, do you honestly expect anyone to believe that your 'source' is reliable? Instead, I'd invite you to read something from actual scientists for a change.
https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0,5&q=climate+change
Over 3.3 million results so it's not like you'll have any trouble picking. It even matches your own criteria: actual scientists, not bureaucrats, celebrities, journalists or politicians.

How about this one, for example?
https://www.nature.com/articles/nature02121
A publication in Nature, the world's most well-known scientific journal and the holy grail of any scientist; allowing only the best of the best.

Except that's not why you're here. You care not for the validity of information, you're merely using the issue of climate change as fuel for your own Dunning-Kruger ailment, aren't you?
What other excuse could you have for not once bothering to investigate what the actual scientific community has to say, and deciding frankly astoundingly that you somehow know better than all of them?
