author: Rykelle Sandidge

text:
¬†@Astral huy¬† 
>Assuming most Americans are capable of thinking critically and forming opinions of their own.

Not even joking, the way our society and education system is set up is dumb as fuck. Personally, up until I transferred out of my shitty public school, I had a difficult time understanding what critical thinking even was, let alone how to do it. Like, when I was given my first critical thinking  question in the 4th grade, I couldn't even process it.

"How do I do this question? We haven't learned the process behind how rain clouds form. How am I supposed to tell you how it works if I haven't been taught how it works yet?"

I was told to think for myself and I could not even. My mind went blank on that, and I basically just made something up that kinda made sense to me (I don't remember what I answered, something about geysers spewing water into the air or something.)

When I found out I was wrong, I got upset because I felt like I was set up to fail, and I was going to get points deducted for a question I wasn't taught the answer to yet. And when the teacher explained that it didn't matter if I got it right, because whether or not I was correct wasn't the point of the question, it was to get me to try and formulate my own ideas and opinions based on what little I know to get my own answer. And my mind was fucking blown. When I had doubts about how this could help me on tests and assignments, I was about to snap at the teacher about it. 

But then I realized, "Wait, if I don't know or forget the answer to a question, I could use this to relearn the answer on my own. HOLY SHIT, WHY WASN'T I TAUGHT THIS SHIT SOONER???????"

I had gone entire school years up until that point without having to answer critical thinking questions. It wasn't because weren't any (there were indeed 'critical thinking's questions in our textbooks), it because in every class I'd been in growing up WE WERE BEING TOLD TO SKIP THEM.

I cringe whenever I think about how lazy brained I was essentially taught to be (and still am at times). I swear this shit is being done on purpose. We are being taught not think for ourselves, only to think on rails  inside of the box we are given.

text:
¬†@FireMageBraixen¬† Unfortunately, your experience is all too common in the education system in the U.S.  I had that same experience in college which is so crazy.  How was critical thinking not taught prior to my college experience?  I also found it highly frustrating, but when I realized that I was essentially learning to think for myself, it was enlightening.  In school I was always taught to find your answer (it usually would be word for word in the text), then "circle A" or "write it out in sentence form".  My learning experience throughout public school was "read question & find answer in the text", the actual articles fiction or nonfiction they didn't matter, it was irrelevant just find the answer and write it down. 
I hope public schools across the country have changed significantly, since I was a student.  Critical thinking is something that students should be challenged to do everyday, in order to create a future where people aren't satisfied by what they hear and see from their favorite news anchor or fellow citizen wearing leopard print.  They actually are interested in seeking out knowledge for themselves from reliable sources and use what they know to think of solutions for a better tomorrow.  Humans have created a lot of environmental problems, we need less people feigning ignorance and more working to create solutions.

text:
¬†@Joy Phillips¬† It's simple. We have two basic options, two choices, and 4 possible results when it comes to climate change. 

Option 1) Climate change is as bad they say and we need to fix the problem now. 
Option 2) It's a hoax like the CNN host said. 
Choice 1) We decide to fix our climate. 
Choice 2) We do nothing, continue on as normal. 

Possible results. 
1) Climate change is real, we fixed it. We can now continue on with one less threat of extinction.
2) Climate change is real, we did nothing. We're all dead. 
3) Climate change is fake, we fixed it. There was never a problem in the first place, but hey our planet is nicer. 
4) Climate change is fake. we did nothing. We simply continue on as we have been, though some scientists might lose their jobs. Possibly prison. 

 I understand it's not that simple, but that's what's broadcast most often on the news. It's real/it's fake, so we simply take those options and compare our action vs inaction and compare the results. You take the realistic extremes so as to not bogged down in the data considering this is a species-wide problem. Then you make your choice.

I personally chose the one without the chance of death.

Also you don't know how science works. Is not important one study of anything. The real important thing is that the consensus of the scientific community agree. 
For example,  almost any physicist today will tell you that the theory of General Relativity by Einstein is the correct picture of the universe and  even though you can find a lot of work assuming that is not correct. The point is that none of that work can prove that GR is not real better than the once who says it is. The same goes for man-made climate change,  95% of the scientist have better evidence of being real than any argument the other part can say.

text: ¬†@Xander¬† I don't know about 8-12 years, or whatever time frame anyone else is putting out there, but there is definitely a problem.  I live in an agricultural area in Ohio, and even the genetically modified crops are starting to suffer, right along with the native plants, and they were engineered to withstand extremes.  We've gone from a variety of weather to just two extremes: hellishly hot and bitterly cold, with a lot of soggy weather in between.  Not having food in the future is starting to look very real to my area of the world.  All those things we buy from the grocery stores do come from a farm somewhere, you know, and what are you, or anyone else going to do when the farmers can't grow it anymore?

author: Jerrell Bevers

text:
I think a good portion of it is that most people view the earth from a specific point of scale. Within everyday life the earth is this infinite unending immutable sphere where no matter what they as an individual do, they could never impact the weather or the earth in any meaningful physical way as a whole. Gradual changes over the course of years to decades of human activity from that scope still doesn‚Äôt seem like it would be able to have an impact. 
Its when you realize or understand that the earth is a closed and finite system that it becomes easier to understand how humans could have an impact. From the standpoint of pollutants (including greenhouse gasses and co2 specifically) the earth is like a bucket with a hole in the bottom. Pollutants are like filling it up with water and nature can eliminate it at a set rate, the hole. But human actions contribute to these factors, heavy pollution due to burning fossil fuels increases the flow into the bucket, while deforestation can shrink the hole at the bottom. When you put more in than can drain out, its only inevitable that it would overflow or spill. The trick to climate science is finding out the rate of filling of that bucket, and what signs of eventually spilling or tipping over will look like.


Tldr: Most people think of the earth as an infinite expanse where it‚Äôs actually more finite than they think. Leading to issues grasping climate science.

text:
¬†@David Anewman¬† - Lots of people say that Climate Change isn't occurring, and the woman in the last clip threw a bone to them by stating that the last two winters were the coldest on record in the last century since the 1980's (which doesn't really make sense).

The same thing happened with evolution. At first, such people flat out denied that evolution has  occurred. Then, in response to overwhelming evidence that even primary school children can understand, some religious leaders promoted the notion that evolution occurs but it doesn't result in speciation events, or at least that's not how humans originated. Centuries later, there are still many people who believe the original rhetoric that evolution hasn't occurred at all. And many people, who accept that evolution occurs but deny that it has resulted in speciation events, hide the fact that they used to vigorously deny that evolution occurs at all. 

Likewise, many people, who accept the fact that Climate Change is occurring but deny that human activity has contributed to it, hide the fact that they used to vigorously deny that Climate Change (or in particular the average global temperature increase) was occurring at all. Neither of their positions are based upon science. Both are based upon tribalism (or greed, in the case of corporate personnel, politicians, and infotainers).

text:
¬†@David Anewman¬† - No, evolution is the changes in allele frequencies in populations of self-replicators, like viruses and living organisms. It's a fact that it occurs. It's been observed many, many times.

Those changes in allele frequencies can also ultimately result in speciation events.

It isn't one animal changing into another. That's absurd. Populations of self-replicators experience changes in allele frequencies over generations. Evolution operates at the population level - not at the individual level. And evolution isn't limited to animals. 

If you're actually interested in being educated about the subject, even if you still disagree that it has resulted in speciation events, you can educate yourself. Read about "ring species" in particular. 

But all of the valid scientific evidence suggests that our species, homo sapiens sapiens, descended from populations of other human species, other great ape species, other ape species, other primate species, other mammal species, other vertebrate species, etc. Even if we can't track our exact evolutionary history, there is no reasonable doubt that we descended from populations of other species. Genetic analysis alone establishes that.
author: loki2240

text:
¬†@David Anewman¬† - Also, it's not my definition of evolution. It's the scientific definition of evolution. The scientific definition of evolution has never been "one animal changing into another animal," and it has never been limited to speciation events.

Actually, before you look up "allele frequencies, " "self-replicators," and "ring species," look up "strawman argument."

text:
¬†@USMC Semper Fidelis¬† That's right. a report came out that said the ozone layer was being destroyed. people believed it and passed policies to correct it, as that was massive imminent threat to the planet. lord knows how many reports came out saying that the climate is changing for the worse due to humans and... nobody believes it. why? because millions of dollars has been spent by companies that stand to lose billions if they're products are no longer to exist. getting rid of aerosol cans was easy. spray bottles work for the same product. but a report that says the product itself is killing the world, that's a business problem. and in our world business trumps everything else because we are taught that it must.

i've read climate prediction models. you have it backwards. no model said we should have melted all of the ice by now. in fact, the earliest models were proven to be far too MODERATE. ie, they predicted the problems would be far off and we're seeing changes much sooner than anticipated by those original models. tech has gotten better with more data collected and more computing power, and modern climate prediction models are much more accurate, and are showing that we are in much more danger than we originally thought, much sooner.

The Ozone layer correction is a great example of what happens when The world comes together and uses science to address problems rather than wishful thinking, politics, greed, and fanaticism. thank you for bringing it up!

Also, climate change is not an American problem. it is a world problem, and we are a World leader. what our leaders say absolutely affects the pressure China, India, Australia or anybody else feels on the issue.
Right now,  China far surpasses the US in environmental hazards being released daily. but they are developing, were as we are already developed. we still have done more than china or india to hurt the environment simply because we started sooner, and have been doing it longer. if it wasn't for our policy shifts at the federal level, and initiatives at the EPA, we wouldn't look so good right now, and would be far worse than them. everything you've said shows the power of good science leading to political policy that corrects problems. exactly what we've stopped doing right now. exactly what climatologists are calling for. exactly what the current administration won't even consider doing.

¬†@Pietro Jenkins¬† I'm gonna be honest, yeah, that's not too far from the truth when it comes to Trump's reasoning. For example, him wanting to build a wall and make it hard for immigrants to immigrate is based on selfish reasoning; America first and always first, who cares if there's a families struggling in other countries, if you don't qualify to be an American citizen and gain citizenship then too bad but Trump wants to hold immigration to strict standards because we don't want people from the outside messing things up. Open borders doesn't always lead to good things, especially for the places that immigrants are flocking to, like France, Ireland, or Spain, who are currently having problems because of immigration, but on the non-selfish side of things would be well...  America may or may not suffer if we ever did have open borders but there would still be a place for families that want to have the American Dream and if that means risking our own country then to hell with it; let's help the people out. 

That's basically the two sides in my view and Trump, he's a strong patriot, enough to were he's selfish about America and he's overly strict on outsiders.
